Literature Review: The measurement of homicide rates is a critical aspect of cross-national research, influencing the understanding of global and regional trends, as well as the development of theoretical explanations for geographical and temporal variations. The increasing number of cross-national homicide studies underscores the importance of scrutinizing how national homicide data are generated and the implications of using different data sources. This literature review examines the impact of homicide measurement on cross-national research, focusing on the four main centralized homicide data sources: the World Health Organization (WHO) Mortality Database, the WHO Global Health Observatory, the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime (UNODC), and the World Bank World Development Indicators. The review highlights the differences in homicide trends, levels, and structural covariates across these data sources and discusses the implications for cross-national research. The WHO Mortality Database emerges as a particularly valuable source due to its methodological rigor and comprehensive coverage, despite the limitations inherent in all four systems. The review concludes with recommendations for researchers to better understand and account for the nuances of homicide data generation in their studies, ensuring more accurate and reliable cross-national comparisons and analyses.
